'''Raoul Bricard''' (23 March 1870 – 1944) is a [[France|French]] [[engineer]] and a [[mathematician]].  He is best known for his work in [[geometry]], especially [[descriptive geometry]] and [[scissors congruence]], and [[kinematics]], especially [[mechanical linkage]]s.

== Biography ==
Bricard taught geometry at [[Ecole Centrale des Arts et Manufactures]].  In 1908 he became a professor of applied geometry at the [[Conservatoire National des Arts et Métiers|National Conservatory of Arts and Crafts]] in [[Paris]].<ref>''[[Science (journal)|Science]]'', vol. 28 (1908), p. 707.</ref> In 1932 he received [[Poncelet Prize]] in [[mathematics]] from the [[French Academy of Sciences|Paris Academy of Sciences]] for his work in geometry.<ref>[http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v131/n3301/abs/131174a0.html "Prize Awards of the Paris Academy of Sciences"], ''[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]'' vol. 131 (1933) 174-175.</ref>

== Work ==
In 1896 Bricard published a paper on [[Hilbert's third problem]], even before the problem was stated by [[David Hilbert|Hilbert]].<ref>R. Bricard, "Sur une question de géométrie relative aux polyèdres", ''[[Nouvelles Annales de Mathématiques|Nouvelles annales de mathématiques]]'', Ser. 3, Vol. 15 (1896), 331-334.</ref>  In it he proved that [[Reflection symmetry|mirror symmetric]] [[polytope]]s are [[scissors congruence|scissors congruent]], and proved a weak version of [[Max Dehn|Dehn]]'s criterion.

In 1897 Bricard published an important investigation on [[flexible polyhedra]].<ref>R. Bricard, [http://www-mathdoc.ujf-grenoble.fr/JMPA/PDF/JMPA_1897_5_3_A5_0.pdf Mémoire sur la théorie de l’octaèdre articulé], ''J. Math. Pures Appl.'', Vol. 3 (1897), 113–150 (see also the [http://math.unm.edu/~vageli/papers/bricard3_6.pdf English translation]).</ref> In it he classified all flexible [[octahedron|octahedra]].<ref>P. Cromwell, ''Polyhedra'', [[Cambridge University Press]], 1997.</ref> This work was the subject of [[Henri Lebesgue|Henri Lebesgue's]] lectures in 1938.<ref>[[Henri Lebesgue|H. Lebesgue]], [http://retro.seals.ch/digbib/en/view?rid=ensmat-001:1967:13::330 "Octaedres articules de Bricard"], ''Enseign. Math. Ser. 2'', 13, No. 3, 175-185.</ref> Later Bricard discovered notable 6-bar linkages.<ref>K. Wohlhart, The two types of the orthogonal Bricard linkage, ''Mechanism and machine theory'',  vol. 28 (1993), 809-817.</ref><ref>{{YouTube|fO1OI-YZS3Y|Bricard 6 Bar Linkage Origami}}.</ref>

Bricard also gave one of the first geometric proofs of [[Morley's trisector theorem]] in 1922.<ref>[[Richard K. Guy]], [https://web.archive.org/web/20120419064244/http://math.ucalgary.ca/files/publications/3414848.pdf "The Lighthouse Theorem, Morley & Malfatti - A Budget of Paradoxes"], ''[[American Mathematical Monthly]]'' 114 (2007) 97-141.</ref><ref>[[Alain Connes]], [http://www.ems-ph.org/journals/newsletter/pdf/2004-12-54.pdf "Symmetries"], ''[[European Mathematical Society]] Newsletter'' No. 54 (December 2004).</ref>

== Books ==
Bricard authored six books, including a mathematics survey in [[Esperanto]].<ref>[http://openlibrary.org/a/OL743075A Raoul Bricard], from [[Open Library]].</ref> He is listed in ''[[Encyclopedia of Esperanto]]''.<ref>[http://www.freeweb.hu/eventoj/steb/gxenerala_naturscienco/enciklopedio-1/encikl.htm Encyclopedia of Esperanto]</ref>
* ''Matematika terminaro kaj krestomatio'' (in Esperanto), Hachette, Paris, 1905
* [http://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/000662067 ''Géométrie descriptive''], O. Doin et fils, 1911
* ''[http://books.google.com/books?id=Grs3AAAAMAAJ Cinématique et mécanismes]'', A. Colin, 1921
* ''Petit traité de perspective'', Vuibert, 1924<ref>{{cite journal|author=Emch, Arnold|authorlink=Arnold Emch|title=Review: ''Petit Traité de Perspective'' by Raoul Bricard|journal=Bull. Amer. Math. Soc.|year=1925|volume=31|issue=9|pages=564|url=http://www.ams.org/journals/bull/1925-31-09/S0002-9904-1925-04125-7/S0002-9904-1925-04125-7.pdf}}</ref>
* ''Leçons de cinématique'', Gauthier-Villars et cie., 1926
* ''Le calcul vectoriel'', A. Colin, 1929
